description.narrative:
Arbitration Council Foundation har ansökt om stöd från Sida om 10.8 miljoner SEK för institutets verksamhet under åren 2014-2018. Insatsen syftar till att främja en miljö för effektiv arbetsmarknadsstyrning för den privata sektorn samt social utveckling genom att tillhandahålla ett välfungerande och trovärdigt system för medling i arbetsmarknadskonflikter. Insatsen har tre huvudmål: 1. tillhandahålla ett effektivt system för medling i arbetsmarknadskonflikter som arbetstagare, arbetsgivare och allmänheten har förtroende för 2. öka kunskap om Arbitration Council och främja förhandlingskapacitet hos arbetstagare och arbetsgivare genom kunskapsfrämjande åtgärder, partnerskap och utåtriktad verksamhet 3. vidmakthålla och fortsatt främja Arbitration Councils institutionella integritet och hållbarhet.
Konsultation med Sida/JUR har skett. Sidas bidrag till Arbitration Council Foundation:s verksamhet är 10.8 miljoner kronor.

The Arbitration Council foundation has submitted a proposal to Sida on project support to the Foundation for 2014-2018. The aim of the intervention is to promote an effective labour market governance environment for private sector and social development through the provision of a well-functioning and credible labour dispute arbitration system. The intervention has three main objectives: (1) providing effective labour dispute resolution services in which workers and employers, and the public have confidence, (2) raising awareness about the Arbitration Council and promote dispute resolution skills of workers and employers through increased capacity building and partnerships and stakeholder outreach activities, and (3) maintaining and promoting institutional integrity and sustainability of the Arbitration Council. The total Sida budget requested is SEK 10.8 million.

To contribute to an effective labour market governance environment for private sector and social development by enhancing the extent to which a well-functioning labour arbitration system builds workers’ and employers’ confidence that labour disputes will be resolved effectively and fairly.

description.narrative: The four-year programme (2014-2018) comes to an end by 31 December 2018. Based on the final completion report, ACF achieved results that can be summarized as follows: (1) On Labour dispute resolution: In total, 781 cases of labour disputes were handled by the Arbitration Council (AC) which is 65% of the target. 75.35% of the cases were resolved successfully through the arbitration process against its target. The AC's services through the case resolution benefited 301,531 workers whereas 80% of them were women, both directly and indirectly. More than 52% of the total cases resolved were from Phnom Penh area. Outside Phnom Penh area such as Siem Reap, Poipet and Takeo provinces, labour dispute arbitration was resolved through AC's mobile hearing services. Regarding this result, it is important to note that the political development in Cambodia during 2017-2018 had led to the decline in collective labour dispute cases referred by the Ministry of Labour to AC. The main cause of this was examined and assessed by ACF and reported to the Embassy and some adaptive measures were initiated with several options such as Study on Direct Access to AC, Study on AC's Operational Environment and Study on Mediation Services to better inform and deal with caseload decline. This was mainly caused by the Government's reforms in policies and legislations that potentially limit access by trade unions (one of the dispute actors) to bring their cases to AC, for example, as required by the Law on Trade Union adopted in 2016. Regarding this matter, the Embassy had dialogue with ACF and brought up to the attention to the Ministry of Labour on several occasions at ambassadorial level and during bilateral human rights dialogues in Sweden in 2016 and in Cambodia in 2017. Prior to the changing context 2017-2018, ACF recorded resolved cases of 338 in 2015 and 248 in 2016 respectively. (2) On Partnership and stakeholder outreach and training: Workers and employers and government officials have increased awareness and capacity regarding labour rights and labour dispute resolution, including increased capacity of women to access and realised their rights. According to the programme evaluation in 2017 by an external consultant (by CDRI team commissioned by ACF) showed that 88% of union and employer organisation leaders and representatives were aware of the works of AC. 80% of 4,397 (42% women) participants attended ACF's trainings (i.e. case preparation, dispute resolution procedures and labour arbitration process) had increased their awareness and capacity to access their rights through the labour arbitration processes. More than 3,2 million people had reached the AC and its services through outreach activities including meetings, workshops, publication, social media, TV and radio broadcasting. Arbitral decisions and awards are published and accessible online which could serve the best interest of the parties, the public, researchers and others. (3) On institutional integrity and sustainability: Institutional integrity is important for AC and ACF to continue gaining trust from relevant stakeholders and ensuring its long-term sustainability. The external evaluation found that 56% of respondents, i.e. union and employer groups viewed AC was independent from Ministry of Labour while 77% reported that the labour arbitration service was credible and effective. 71% of respondents considered the arbitration awards to be of satisfactory quality and no client's reporting of unofficial fee payment to the arbitrators and staff for their case resolution. To sustain institutionally and financially, AC/ACF has developed a blueprint for financial contribution collection system, in which a multi-party financial contribution model (i.e. contributions by the government, workers, employers, and donors) was adopted with commitment from both the Ministry of Labour and the Ministry of Economy and Finance to increase their funding level to support AC. It should be mentioned that during the programme period, ACF took some measures to mainstream gender equality perspective in the programme which led to sex disaggregated data for some activities such as hearing (35% of participants were women), in-house capacity building for arbitrators and staff (59% were women), external trainings and conferences (42% were women), and beneficiaries (appr. 80% are women workers). Nevertheless, these measures were assessed to be insufficient as no qualitative results reported yet. The Embassy had a dialogue with ACF on this issue and required ACF to further strengthen its gender equality perspective in the new programme.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
